awd_titl_txt: Explicit Methods for Finding Rational Points on Varieties
awd_abstract_narration:
The project concerns various problems tied to number theory and algebraic geometry. Specifically, finding rational solutions to a system of polynomial equations has been the subject of active research since the ancient times. These rational points are quite sparse; Faltings (1983) proved that there are only finitely many rational points on curves of genus at least 2, and the minimalist conjecture asserts that most elliptic curves have low ranks as well. The sparsity of rational points have an application in the field of cryptography, as the explicit computation of various invariants of elliptic curves is often difficult.

This project aims to further this point of view using various techniques coming from number theory, algebraic geometry, and logic. On one hand, the PI wishes to develop explicit p-adic methods that help find these rational points. On the other hand, heuristic arguments that approximate the difficulty of these methods can be helpful. These heuristics can range from finding a simple model for certain arithmetic invariants tied to the distribution of rational points, to arguments based in logic, to the estimate of computational complexity in the explicit computation of these invariants. These heuristics could have real-life consequences in, for example, approximating the hardness of isogeny-based cryptography.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
During the period of the award DMS-1902199, the PI was engaged in three major research directions, which will be elaborated on below. In addition to the articles written on these subjects, the PI also provided various services to the mathematical community. The PI supervised one graduate student and four postdoctoral fellows, organized six conferences, gave many talks at local and international level events, and became the faculty advisor to the AWM chapter at the Ohio State University.


1. Arithmetic Statistics: The PI published two papers in this area, and is working on two more projects. The first paper (with Poonen, Voight, and Wood) concerns the heuristic that suggest the possibility that the ranks of elliptic curves may be bounded. While this heuristic seems to predict the behaviour of ranks on general families of elliptic curves, there are some specific families with extra arithmetic that violate this heuristic -- the PI is working on refining this heuristic (with Klagsbrun and Weiss). In addition, with Fisher and Ho, the PI has published another paper that computes the proportion of locally soluble hypersurfaces in products of projective spaces.


2. Hilbert's tenth problem: The PI published one paper in this area in the duration of the award -- that the Inverse Galois Problem is Turing reducible from Hilbert's Tenth Problem over Q. In addition, the PI's graduate student, supported by this award, is working on a possible approach towards Hilbert's tenth problem over Q using ideas from arithmetic geometry. This paper is currently being revised, and the graduate student is working on some follow-up projects as well.


3. Supersingular Isogeny Diffie-Hellman key exchange: In the duration of the award, the PI was interested in trying to identify precisely the generators of endomorphism rings of supersingular elliptic curves via cycles of l-isogeny graphs. The PI wrote two papers (with Bank, Camacho-Navarro, Eisentraeger, Hallgren, Leonardi, and Morrison) on partial progress obtained following this idea. In July 2022, it was shown that SIDH is not secure against quantum algorithms, but the problem of computing the generators of endomorphism rings still remains open.


Last Modified: 11/30/2023
Modified by: Jennifer Park
